title-group.article-title: A Challenge to Providers of Clinical Nutrition Therapy

body.p: We take great responsibility to provide optimal clinical nutrition therapies for the patients in our care. Given these efforts, how well are we doing?
That is not a rhetorical question! But it is a question we don’t have a good answer to.
Thousands of patients receive clinical nutrition therapy every year; however,

list-item.p: Who are these patients? Who are their providers?
What type of therapy are they receiving? What monitoring is associated with their care? What complications do they experience?
When is the therapy administered? When do they follow-up with their providers?
Where do they receive their therapy? Where is their clinician located?
Why are they receiving nutrition support?
How effective and safe is their therapy? How long will their therapy last?

body.p: Canada and Spain are two countries that lead the way in collecting such data on patients receiving home parenteral nutrition (HPN).1,2 HPN prevalence in the United States was estimated to be 140 patients per million persons3; however, these data are nearly 20 years old and comprehensive data is lacking.

Our inability to answer such questions limits patient outcomes, funding for services, and the very rationale for clinical nutrition therapies. In this issue of JPEN, Guenter and colleagues4 describe a Web-based registry for patients receiving HPN launched in early 2011. This registry, titled Sustain™, provides us the opportunity to collect data that can then be used to measure outcomes, benchmark programs and ultimately improve patient care. Expansion of the registry to other populations and therapies is planned for future phases of the project.

In May 2012, A.S.P.E.N. announced that 13 organizations were currently entering patient data, whereas an additional 28 organizations had enrolled and were gaining approval to participate. Data collected to date (n = 324) included demographics, diagnoses, and goals for PN, medications, PN formulas, types of catheters, other oral and enteral intake, quality of life, and functional status. As indicated in the article, the registry is open to all sites (hospital and home based) who care for new or existing HPN patients.

I personally challenge you and your colleagues to take the time to participate in this important project. It is crucial that data are captured from as many patients as possible, across diverse clinical care environments. Such data will arm us with the knowledge to provide excellent clinical nutrition therapy and justify the importance of our interventions.
As we look toward the future together, let’s ensure the data lead the way.
